concept.title: Cluster setup considerations
concept.shortdesc: Proper configuration of I/O subsystems is critical for the optimal performance and operation and performance of Couchbase Server.

section.title: Storage
section.p: These are the most common best practices recommended for storage configuration:

dlentry.dt: Isolate the data and index at the physical disk level
dlentry.dd: For the best performance on Couchbase Server nodes with the data service, isolate the bucket data and view index at the physical disk level.
Combining different workloads (workloads with different I/O and latency characteristics) can have negative effects on overall performance.

With MDS, you can have different disk storage configurations for nodes running the data and index services if this fits your use case needs. The index servers can have SSD-backed storage for better performance.

dlentry.dt: Use RAID 1+0 (or RAID 1) if replication factor is 1
dlentry.dd: If replication factor is 2 or higher, the system administrator can rely on database-level replication for data durability.
When formatting the partitions for the SQL Server data files, it is recommended that you use a 64-KB allocation unit size for data, logs, and tempdb. See SQL Server Best Practices.

Follow the Disk Partition Alignment Best Practices for SQL Server. These best practices apply both when the cluster size is the NTFS default (4,096 bytes) or the recommended size for the SQL Server (64 Kb).
